articles.content:
Click to expand Image The grandchildren of Patrice Emery Lumumba during a session of the Brussels council chamber, in the case concerning the 1961 murder of Lumumba the first elected Prime Minister of the DRC Congo, January 20, 2026. © 2026 by Benoit Doppagne/Belga/Sipa USA via AP Photo

On January 20, a Belgian court held a closed-door hearing to determine whether to pursue a criminal case against the last living former Belgian official for his alleged involvement in the 1961 assassination of the first democratically elected prime minister of the Democratic Republic of Congo, Patrice Émery Lumumba, following the country’s independence from Belgian colonial rule.

The historic case was brought by Lumumba’s family, whose perseverance could now lead to the first instance of a European court pursuing individual criminal responsibility for a crime linked to European colonial rule. Former European colonial powers considered Lumumba a threat to their political and economic interests, as he symbolized African self-determination and decolonization.

During a press conference following this week’s hearing, Lumumba’s family described the case as a step toward “justice and truth.” A decision is expected on March 17.

The importance of the case cannot be overstated as former European colonial powers remain unwilling to take legal responsibility for their colonial crimes and abuses. Instead democratic leaders should be genuinely reckoning with historical injustices and taking action consistent with international human rights law and norms on justice, dignity, and accountability.

Governments should build on the momentum for reparations seen in 2025 at the United Nations, African Union (AU), the Caribbean Community (CARICOM), and at national levels to address enduring global systemic racial and economic injustices rooted in legacies of colonialism, enslavement, and the slave trade.

Last year, governments at the UN committed to a Second International Decade for People of African Descent. Meanwhile, the AU dedicated the year to reparatory justice, later extending it to a decade. The AU also joined reparatory efforts with CARICOM.

International human rights law and standards create obligations for states to provide effective remedies and reparations for gross rights violations, many of which occurred during colonization. But political unwillingness continues to denyaffected communities justice.

Without addressing historical injustices, cycles of inequality, exclusion, and violence will persist. Reparations are therefore not symbolic but a legal obligation and a necessary foundation for a just and equitable future.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a historic legal case potentially holding a former European official criminally responsible for colonial-era crimes, representing a significant step toward justice and reparations for colonial abuses. This has broad societal significance as it addresses systemic racial and economic injustices rooted in colonialism, with international momentum supporting reparatory justice. The story is focused, detailed, and highlights a meaningful, positive real-world impact on justice and accountability.
articles.personality_title: Belgian court reviews case on Congo leader Lumumba’s 1961 assassination
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Patrice Émery Lumumba was the first democratically elected prime minister of the Democratic Republic of Congo after it gained independence from Belgium. He was assassinated in 1961, shortly after independence. European colonial powers saw Lumumba as a threat to their control and interests in Africa.

**What happened** – On January 20, 2026, a Belgian court held a private hearing to decide whether to start a criminal case against the last living former Belgian official accused of involvement in Lumumba’s assassination. The case was brought by Lumumba’s family. A decision from the court is expected by March 17.

**Impact** – This case could be the first time a European court holds an individual officially responsible for crimes linked to European colonial rule. It marks an important moment in the long fight for justice by Lumumba’s family and highlights ongoing efforts to address the harms caused by colonialism. The case also connects with wider international moves toward reparations and justice for people affected by colonial-era abuses.

**What's next step** – The court’s decision in March will determine if the case moves forward. Meanwhile, governments and international groups like the United Nations, African Union, and Caribbean Community continue working on reparations and justice related to colonial history. These efforts aim to correct lasting inequalities and recognize legal obligations to affected communities.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A Belgian court’s review of a colonial-era assassination case could open new paths for justice and reparations linked to European colonial crimes.

articles.title: Lords back UK social media ban for under-16s
articles.summary: It comes as the government looks into its own potential ban, with a consultation closing in the summer.
articles.content:
Lords back UK social media ban for under-16s

6 hours ago Share Save Paul Seddon Political reporter Share Save

PA Media

The House of Lords has backed a move to ban under-16s in the UK from social media platforms. By 261 votes to 150, opposition peers voted to support a ban through an amendment to the government's schools bill. The government has indicated it will try to overturn the amendment in the Commons, whilst it holds its own consultation on a potential ban. But this Commons vote could prove politically tricky for ministers, as some Labour MPs have said they also favour a ban for under-16s.

Political momentum at Westminster in favour of a ban has grown since Australia's move last month to ban under-16s from 10 major platforms, with more than 60 Labour MPs recently joining the Conservative Party in urging a similar move. However, others some campaigners and children's charities have come out against the idea. Under the amendment backed by peers, the government would get a year to decide which platforms should be unavailable to under-16s, with companies forced to put in place "highly effective" age checks to police access. It was supported by Conservative, Liberal Democrat and crossbench peers, as well as two from Labour. Former Tory schools minister Lord Nash, one of those sponsoring the proposed change, said children's use of social media was a "societal catastrophe" and a ban would give teenagers a "few more years to mature" before using the platforms. He said there was "overwhelming" evidence about the damage caused by teenage social media use, arguing it was linked to mental health problems, online radicalisation and disruptive behaviour in classrooms. He dismissed the government's consultation as a "last-minute attempt to kick the can down the road", adding: "What are we waiting for? We know our children are being harmed".

'Complex issue'

Online safety campaigner Baroness Kidron, another peer supporting the ban, said she worried the government's consultation would become the "playground of the tech lobbyist". "The government has shown it will only act under pressure, not principle," she added. However, other peers urged caution about the proposal, with Labour peer Lord Knight of Weymouth arguing it could push teenagers towards "less regulated platforms". He added that a blanket ban would also deprive children of the more positive aspects of social media, adding that a better approach was to "listen to young people" during the government consultation. Several charities and campaign groups, including the NSPCC, have said a full ban risks "unintended consequences," and have called instead for stronger enforcement of existing child safety rules. Asked earlier whether it would support the Lords' amendment, Sir Keir Starmer's spokesperson said: "Our position is clear. We won't accept the amendment. "This is an extremely complex issue. We believe the right thing to do is to gather the necessary evidence and insight before changing the law." The government consultation, which will run for three months, will assess the merits of a ban for under-16s, as well as overnight curfews and actions to prevent "doom-scrolling". It will also look at whether more robust age checks could be implemented by social media firms, which could be forced to remove or limit features "which drive compulsive use of social media". The Liberal Democrats supported Lord Nash's amendment after failing to win support for their own rival plan to restrict children's social media use. The party added that it would put pressure on the government to "come forward with concrete proposals for a workable plan". "While we may differ on the best approach, we believe there is a shared responsibility to act," added education spokesperson Munira Wilson.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on the UK House of Lords backing a social media ban for under-16s, aiming to protect children's mental health and online safety. This legislative move has broad societal significance as it addresses youth well-being and digital safety on a national scale. The story provides detailed context on the political debate, the rationale behind the ban, and the concerns raised, showing a substantive discussion on protecting children from harmful online content.
articles.personality_title: UK House of Lords supports social media ban for under-16s to protect young users
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – There is growing concern about how social media affects children’s mental health and safety. Recently, countries like Australia have started banning kids under 16 from using major social media platforms. The UK government is also thinking about similar rules and is currently asking the public for their opinions.

**What happened** – The UK House of Lords voted in favor of an amendment to ban children under 16 from using social media. This vote happened recently, with 261 peers supporting the ban and 150 against it. The amendment is part of a schools bill and would require social media companies to check users’ ages carefully and block younger users. Some politicians from different parties supported this change, while others, including some charities, want more careful study before making a decision.

**Impact** – This move is important because it shows a big step towards protecting children from harmful effects linked to social media, such as mental health problems and exposure to bad content. It also pushes companies to improve age checks, which could make online spaces safer. However, there is debate because some worry a ban might push kids to use unregulated sites or miss out on positive experiences social media can offer.

**What’s next step** – The UK government is holding a consultation that will last three months to gather more evidence and opinions. They will look at the ban idea, as well as other options like setting time limits for social media use and stopping harmful habits like endless scrolling. After this, the government will decide whether to accept the ban or suggest other rules.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The UK House of Lords has voted to ban social media use for under-16s, aiming to protect young people’s well-being while the government studies the best way to keep children safe online.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Chambre des Lords soutient l’interdiction des réseaux sociaux pour les moins de 16 ans au Royaume-Uni
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les inquiétudes grandissent concernant l’impact des réseaux sociaux sur la santé mentale et la sécurité des enfants. Récemment, des pays comme l’Australie ont commencé à interdire aux moins de 16 ans d’utiliser les grandes plateformes sociales. Le gouvernement britannique réfléchit aussi à des règles similaires et consulte actuellement le public.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – La Chambre des Lords du Royaume-Uni a voté en faveur d’un amendement pour interdire aux enfants de moins de 16 ans d’utiliser les réseaux sociaux. Ce vote a eu lieu récemment, avec 261 pairs pour et 150 contre. Cet amendement fait partie d’un projet de loi sur les écoles et demanderait aux entreprises de réseaux sociaux de vérifier l’âge des utilisateurs et de bloquer les plus jeunes. Certains politiciens de différents partis soutiennent ce changement, tandis que d’autres, y compris des associations, souhaitent une étude plus approfondie avant de décider.

**Impact** – Cette décision est importante car elle montre une avancée pour protéger les enfants des effets négatifs liés aux réseaux sociaux, comme les problèmes de santé mentale ou l’exposition à des contenus inappropriés. Elle incite aussi les entreprises à renforcer les contrôles d’âge, ce qui pourrait rendre les espaces en ligne plus sûrs. Cependant, certains craignent que l’interdiction pousse les enfants vers des sites moins contrôlés ou les prive des aspects positifs des réseaux sociaux.

**Étape suivante** – Le gouvernement britannique organise une consultation de trois mois pour recueillir plus d’informations et d’opinions. Il étudiera l’idée de l’interdiction, ainsi que d’autres mesures comme des limites de temps d’utilisation ou la lutte contre le défilement compulsif. Ensuite, il décidera d’adopter ou non l’interdiction ou de proposer d’autres règles.

**Une phrase clé** – La Chambre des Lords a voté pour interdire les réseaux sociaux aux moins de 16 ans afin de protéger leur bien-être, tandis que le gouvernement étudie la meilleure manière de garantir leur sécurité en ligne.
articles.personality_title_es: La Cámara de los Lores del Reino Unido apoya la prohibición de redes sociales para menores de 16 años
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Crece la preocupación sobre cómo las redes sociales afectan la salud mental y la seguridad de los niños. Recientemente, países como Australia han empezado a prohibir que los menores de 16 años usen plataformas sociales importantes. El gobierno del Reino Unido también está considerando reglas similares y actualmente está consultando a la población.

**Qué pasó** – La Cámara de los Lores del Reino Unido votó a favor de una enmienda que prohíbe a los niños menores de 16 años usar redes sociales. La votación fue reciente, con 261 miembros a favor y 150 en contra. Esta enmienda forma parte de un proyecto de ley escolar y exigiría a las empresas de redes sociales verificar la edad de los usuarios y bloquear a los más jóvenes. Algunos políticos de diferentes partidos apoyan el cambio, mientras que otros, incluyendo organizaciones benéficas, piden estudiar más antes de decidir.

**Impacto** – Esta acción es importante porque representa un paso para proteger a los niños de efectos negativos relacionados con las redes sociales, como problemas de salud mental y exposición a contenido dañino. También impulsa a las empresas a mejorar los controles de edad, lo que podría hacer que los espacios en línea sean más seguros. Sin embargo, hay preocupación de que la prohibición pueda llevar a los niños a usar sitios menos regulados o que pierdan experiencias positivas de las redes sociales.

**Próximo paso** – El gobierno del Reino Unido realizará una consulta de tres meses para recopilar más evidencias y opiniones. Analizarán la idea de la prohibición, así como otras opciones como poner límites de tiempo al uso y evitar hábitos dañinos como el desplazamiento continuo. Después decidirán si aceptan la prohibición o proponen otras reglas.

**Conclusión en una frase** – La Cámara de los Lores votó para prohibir el uso de redes sociales a menores de 16 años, buscando proteger su bienestar mientras el gobierno estudia cómo mantener a los niños seguros en línea.

articles.title: Press release - MEPs approve “enhanced cooperation” for €90 billion EU support loan to Ukraine
articles.summary: On Wednesday, Parliament gave its green light to a decision by the Council to apply the enhanced cooperation procedure to provide Ukraine with a €90 billion support loan.Committee on BudgetsCommittee on International TradeCommittee on Security and Defence Source : © European Union, 2026 - EP
articles.content:
The EU support loan was agreed at the European Council summit in Brussels on 18 December 2025 and presented by the European Commission on 14 January 2026. As Czechia, Hungary and Slovakia have opted out from backing the loan, the agreement was taken under the enhanced cooperation procedure, a mechanism that allows willing EU member states to collaborate in specific areas. According to the treaties, the enhanced cooperation procedure requires the consent of the European Parliament.

The procedure was approved by 499 votes in favour, 135 against with 24 abstentions. On Tuesday, MEPs decided to fast-track their work on the loan and the accompanying proposals, which must now be agreed between Parliament and Council under the ordinary legislative procedure.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on the European Parliament's approval of a significant €90 billion support loan to Ukraine, representing a major financial and political commitment to aid a country affected by conflict. This support has broad humanitarian and geopolitical implications, potentially contributing to stability, reconstruction, and relief for millions of people. The decision involves multiple EU member states and uses an enhanced cooperation mechanism, demonstrating meaningful international collaboration. The article provides sufficient context about the procedure and voting, focusing clearly on this impactful financial aid decision.
articles.personality_title: European Parliament approves €90 billion support loan to Ukraine through enhanced cooperation
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union (EU) wants to help Ukraine with a large financial loan. However, some EU countries like Czechia, Hungary, and Slovakia chose not to take part in this support. To move forward, the EU used a special method called "enhanced cooperation," which lets willing countries work together even if others don’t join.

**What happened** – On Wednesday, the European Parliament voted to approve this plan. They agreed to provide Ukraine with a €90 billion loan to help with the challenges it faces. The loan was first agreed upon by EU leaders in December 2025 and then officially proposed by the European Commission in January 2026. The Parliament gave its approval with 499 votes in favor, 135 against, and 24 abstentions.

**Impact** – This loan is one of the biggest financial supports the EU has offered to a single country. It shows strong cooperation among many EU members and offers Ukraine important help for rebuilding and dealing with the effects of conflict. The use of enhanced cooperation means that even if some countries are not involved, others can still provide aid quickly and effectively.

**What’s next step** – Now, the European Parliament and the Council will work together to finalize the details of the loan and related plans. This process will happen quickly to ensure Ukraine receives support as soon as possible.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU is moving forward with a €90 billion loan to support Ukraine, using a special cooperation method to include willing member countries despite some opting out.

articles.title: Press release - European Parliament stands behind air passenger rights
articles.summary: MEPs want to maintain a traveller’s right to compensation for a three-hour delay while also pushing for simpler reimbursement procedures and free cabin luggage.Committee on Transport and Tourism Source : © European Union, 2026 - EP
articles.content:
On Wednesday, European Parliament adopted its position (632 votes to 15 and with nine abstentions) on a revision of EU air passenger rights rules changes suggested by EU member states in June 2025. MEPs voted against a push by EU ministers to weaken air passenger rights, which have been in force since 2004 and the purpose of which are to ensure passengers are sufficiently protected against travel disruption.

Securing existing rights

MEPs want to maintain the right for air travellers to be reimbursed or re-routed and to claim compensation if a flight is delayed by more than three hours, if it is cancelled, or if they are denied boarding. The Council is pushing for compensation to apply only after a four-to-six-hour delay, depending on the flight distance.

Parliament is also against decreasing the current compensation amounts for flight disruptions and suggests they should be set at between €300 and €600 depending on the flight distance. Member state governments want to set compensation at between €300 and €500.

With the responsibility of airlines limited to situations within their control, Parliament wants to renew the list of the extraordinary circumstances that would allow them to waive their responsibility to pay compensation, circumstances which currently include natural disasters, war, weather conditions or unforeseen labour disputes affecting the air operator, airport or air navigation service provider. MEPs want this list to be exhaustive and for the Commission to update it regularly.

The duty to provide stranded passengers with refreshments every two hours beyond the initial departure time, a meal after three hours, and an overnight stay of a maximum of three nights for long delays, should be retained in all circumstances, MEPs agree with the Council. The three-night limit would, they argue, offer airlines greater predictability and spare them undue financial costs.





Faster and simpler reimbursement

MEPs want the introduction of pre-filled forms for compensation and reimbursement requests, to simplify claims processing and help passengers and airlines avoid the use of claims agencies. According to the draft rules, air carriers would need to send passengers experiencing travel disruptions (cancellation or delays) a pre-filled form within 48 hours of the incident (Council’s position requires a pre-filled form only after cancellation, not after long delays). Travellers would then have one year to file a request.

Strengthening traveller protection

Parliament wants passengers to have the right to carry with them onto the airplane, at no additional cost, one personal item (such as a handbag, backpack or laptop) and one small piece of hand luggage with maximum dimensions of 100 cm (combined length, width and height) and seven kilograms.

MEPs also want to scrap the additional fees travellers are sometimes forced to pay for correcting passenger name errors or for checking into their flight. Passengers should retain the right to choose between digital and paper boarding passes, they add.

Vulnerable passengers

MEPs also pay special attention to passengers with disabilities or reduced mobility. These travellers should have the right to compensation, rerouting and assistance by airlines if they miss a flight due to airport’s failure to help them reach the gate on time, the text says. Passengers with reduced mobility, pregnant women, infants, and children in a pram with an accompanying person should be given priority when boarding, while their accompanying persons should be seated in an adjacent seat without incurring extra charges.

Quote

Rapporteur Andrey Novakov (EPP, BG) said: ''Parliament is ready to continue the fight for clearer and more predictable rules for airlines and a stronger aviation sector, but not at the expense of passengers. Our baseline is clear: we are determined to improve rather than dilute air passenger rights. We insist that reducing delays has significant overall benefits for Europe’s economy. Therefore, the three-hour threshold for compensation, the existing compensation levels, pre-filled forms and enforceable safeguards remain our red lines. We are counting on EU transport ministers to reconsider their position so that together we may find a mutually acceptable outcome. Citizens expect us to deliver."





Next steps

Under the second reading procedure Parliament’s position will be sent to the Council. If the Council does not accept all of Parliament’s amendments, a so-called “Conciliation Committee” will be convened to find an agreement on the final shape of the bill.

Background information

Since Parliament made proposals on air passenger rights reform in 2014, the progress to update these rules has stalled for 11 years in Council. In June 2025, however, EU ministers reached a political agreement, opening the way for negotiations with Parliament. The interinstitutional talks started in October 2025, but the negotiations did not result in an agreement, forcing Parliament to proceed with the adoption of its second reading position.

articles.personality_title: European Parliament protects and improves air passenger rights
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union has rules to protect air travelers if their flights are delayed, canceled, or if they are denied boarding. These rules have been in place since 2004, but EU member states recently suggested changes that could weaken these protections.

**What happened** – On June 2026, the European Parliament voted strongly to keep and improve passenger rights. They rejected proposals to reduce compensation for delays and insisted that passengers should be compensated if their flight is delayed by more than three hours. They also want to make it easier for passengers to claim compensation by introducing pre-filled forms and to allow free cabin luggage for travelers.

**Impact** – This decision means millions of travelers across Europe will continue to have strong protections when flights go wrong. Passengers will not only keep their right to fair compensation but will also benefit from simpler claims and better treatment for people with disabilities, pregnant women, and families with children. It sets clear rules for airlines and helps passengers avoid extra fees.

**What's next step** – The European Parliament’s position will now be sent to the EU Council, where member states will discuss it. If they disagree, a special committee will work to find a final agreement. This process will decide the exact rules passengers will have in the future.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The European Parliament has taken a clear stand to protect and improve the rights of air travelers, ensuring fair treatment and easier compensation across the EU.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Parlement européen protège et améliore les droits des passagers aériens
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’Union européenne dispose de règles pour protéger les voyageurs aériens en cas de retard, d’annulation ou de refus d’embarquement. Ces règles existent depuis 2004, mais des États membres ont récemment proposé des modifications qui pourraient affaiblir ces protections.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En juin 2026, le Parlement européen a voté massivement pour maintenir et améliorer les droits des passagers. Il a rejeté les propositions de réduction des compensations et a insisté pour que les passagers soient indemnisés en cas de retard supérieur à trois heures. Il souhaite aussi faciliter les demandes d’indemnisation avec des formulaires pré-remplis et autoriser un bagage cabine gratuit.

**Impact** – Cette décision garantit à des millions de voyageurs en Europe des protections solides en cas de problème de vol. Les passagers conserveront leur droit à une indemnisation juste, bénéficieront de démarches simplifiées et d’un meilleur traitement des personnes vulnérables comme les personnes handicapées, les femmes enceintes et les familles avec enfants. Cela fixe des règles claires pour les compagnies aériennes et évite des frais supplémentaires pour les passagers.

**Prochaine étape** – La position du Parlement sera envoyée au Conseil de l’UE, où les États membres en discuteront. En cas de désaccord, un comité spécial sera créé pour trouver un accord final. Ce processus décidera des règles exactes pour les passagers à l’avenir.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le Parlement européen a pris position pour protéger et améliorer les droits des voyageurs aériens, assurant un traitement équitable et une indemnisation plus simple dans toute l’UE.
articles.personality_title_es: El Parlamento Europeo protege y mejora los derechos de los pasajeros aéreos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Unión Europea tiene reglas para proteger a los viajeros aéreos si sus vuelos se retrasan, cancelan o les niegan el embarque. Estas reglas existen desde 2004, pero algunos países miembros propusieron cambios que podrían debilitar estas protecciones.

**Qué pasó** – En junio de 2026, el Parlamento Europeo votó para mantener y mejorar los derechos de los pasajeros. Rechazaron reducir las compensaciones y pidieron que los pasajeros reciban indemnización si el vuelo se retrasa más de tres horas. También quieren facilitar las reclamaciones con formularios prellenados y permitir un equipaje de mano gratuito.

**Impacto** – Esta decisión protege a millones de viajeros en Europa con derechos fuertes cuando sus vuelos tienen problemas. Los pasajeros conservarán el derecho a una compensación justa, tendrán trámites más simples y mejor atención para personas con discapacidad, embarazadas y familias con niños. Establece reglas claras para las aerolíneas y evita cargos extra.

**Próximo paso** – La posición del Parlamento se enviará al Consejo de la UE, donde los países miembros la discutirán. Si no hay acuerdo, se formará un comité especial para encontrar una solución final. Este proceso definirá las reglas que tendrán los pasajeros en el futuro.

**Resumen en una frase** – El Parlamento Europeo ha defendido y mejorado los derechos de los pasajeros aéreos para garantizar un trato justo y compensaciones más fáciles en toda la UE.
